## Gapfilling in Samoa

Carpet plot for Samoa

Let's have a look at the percent gapfilling by goal. This shows that there are several goals that have very little gapfilling in terms of the data involved: 

AO, SPP, LSP, SP, ICO, and NP


```{r, echo=FALSE}
scores_gf <- scores_gf_csv %>% 
  filter(region_id == rgn_global$rgn_id) %>% 
  filter(dimension == "score") %>%
  select(goal, percent_gapfilled = score) %>%
  arrange(percent_gapfilled) 

scores_gf %>%
  knitr::kable()
```



We can actually compare the percent gapfilling by goal to the scores per goal. It looks like HAB had the highest score but also some of the highest percentage of gapfilling. 

```{r, echo=FALSE}
scores <- scores_csv %>% 
  filter(region_id == rgn_global$rgn_id) %>% 
  filter(region_id == rgn_global$rgn_id) %>% 
  filter(dimension == "score", 
         year == max(year)) %>%
  select(goal, score) %>%
  arrange(goal) 

scores_plot <- scores %>%
  left_join(scores_gf, by = "goal") # this will remove LIV, ECO, LE because not tracked for gapfilling

ggplot(data = scores_plot, aes(x = score, y = percent_gapfilled, label = goal)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_text(aes(label = goal), nudge_x = 3, nudge_y = 1)

## can also assign above to p then:
# ggplotly(p)
```
